item.title: You should make a new programming language
item.description: Every software engineer uses a programming language, usually multiple. Few of us make programming languages. This makes sense, because the work we need to get done can typically be done just fine in the languages that exist. Those already have people making them better. Let's focus on the task at hand.

item.title: Default map value
item.description: In this post, I’ll explain how to provide a default value when querying an absent key in a hash map in different programming languages. Java Let’s start with Java, my first professional programming language. In older versions, retrieving a value from a map required using the get() method: Map map = new HashMap(); (1) Object value = map.get(new Object()); (2) if (value == null) { value = 'default';
item.author: (Nicolas Fränkel)

item.title: One-Year RSU Grants are for Suckers or Quantifying the Free Option Value of the Four-Year Varietal - Daniel D. McKinnon
item.description: TL;DR Independent of the fact that stonks usually go up, equal-vesting, four-year RSU grants are worth ~26% more than their face value due to the embedded optionality and ~13% more than the equivalent one-year grant. I leave figuring out the … Continue reading →

item.title: Building static binaries in Nix — kokada
item.description: I recently had laser eye surgery for my near-sightedness, and while evaluating if I could have the surgery I discovered that I was suffering from dry eyes. Thanks to this, my ophthalmologist recommended that every 20 minutes while using screens, I look somewhere 20 feet away for 20 seconds, a technique known as 20-20-20 rule.

item.title: What's Next? (2024 edition)
item.description: I have, as they say, some personal news to share. On Monday I (along with some very talented teammates, see below if you’re hiring) was laid off from Microsoft as part of a reorganization. Like my Moving to Microsoft post, I wanted to jot down some of the things I got to work on. Reflections It should go without saying that all of this was a team effort. I’ve been incredibly fortunate to have great teammates over the years, but the team building out the Planetary Computer was especially fantastic.

item.title: Repair and Remain

item.title: There Is No Antimemetics Division
item.description:
An antimeme is an idea with self-censoring properties; an idea which, by its intrinsic nature, discourages or prevents people from spreading it.
Antimemes are real. Think of any piece of information which you wouldn't share with anybody, like passwords, taboos and dirty secr...

item.title: Okay, I really like WezTerm
item.description: A guide to configuring WezTerm using its Lua API. Focuses on appearance, keybindings, multiplexing, workspace navigation, and status bar (powerline) setup.

item.title: Passing Arguments to VS Code when Debugging in C# and .NET | no dogma blog
item.description: It used to be easier to pass arguments to an application being debugged in VS Code, but in some one of the updates this changed. Here's how to get it working again.
